Hi Derek, Ken

Derek James wrote:

> I was reading Ken's updated paper on Competitive
> Coevolution through Evolutionary Complexification, and
> I came across the Evolution of Complexity section
> (6.1):
>
> http://www-2.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs/project/jair/pub/volume21/stanley04a-html/node6.html#SECTION00063000000000000000

[...]

All good questions. I have to admit that I've never fully convinced 
myself that a population's complexity (within NEAT)  wouldn't spiral out 
of control without, say, some kind of punishment for complex (long) 
genomes. Bad additions will result in a lower fitness and will therefore 
cause those particular genomes to be selected against. But what about 
neutral additions? connections that are neither good nor bad - what is 
preventing these connections from accumulating and clogging up the whole 
simulation?

This is one of the reasons I'm eager to get into the guts of NEAT and 
really understand what is going on. I can imagine that in short runs 
that connection accumulation would not be a problem, but in long runs 
where evolution stagnates... ? Off the top of my head I can't see any 
reason why deletion of connections shouldn't be included as a possible 
mutation - I will certainly be trying this out.

Regarding the correlation between complexity and fitness. I agree that 
generally I wouldn't assume the two to be linked, but since  the only 
way of improving  is via mutation, and the only mutation is 'add a 
connection/node' then good genomes can reasonably be assumed to have 
more connections and nodes.  Although I have convieniently overlooked 
sexual reproduction (which can improve without increasing genome length) 
and mutation of connection weights! So we're back to square one.

Colin
